Objectives: The main purpose of the study was to explore the potential of deep learning in classifying and recognizing the mental load in workers engaged in hazardous operations, aiming to enhance occupational suitability, psychological training, and personnel adjustments in high-risk industries.
Problem: The study addresses the problem of how the psychophysiological state of workers in high-risk industries, influenced by mental load, impacts work efficiency, overall well-being, and safety, contributing to industrial accidents.
Data: The study collected physiological data from thirty chemical and safety professionals. The data included electroencephalography (EEG), photoplethysmography (PPG), and electrooculography (EOG) signals.
Methods_Techniques: The study employed a combination of four feature selection and extraction techniques for multi-modal information fusion and feature dimensionality reduction. Both deep learning (DL) and traditional machine learning (ML) techniques were utilized to construct a mental load recognition model. The performance of the model was evaluated using six reliable metrics.
Results: The study found that sensitivity testing successfully induced mental load states, causing significant changes in EEG, PPG, and EOG indexes. Feature dimensionality reduction improved recognition effectiveness, with Random Forest Feature Selection (RFS) highlighted as the best method. The combination of RFS and a 1D-convolutional neural network (1D-CNN) model demonstrated excellent recognition effectiveness, achieving an overall accuracy of 90.67% and a high mental load recognition accuracy of 95%.

Objectives: The main purpose of this study was to employ machine learning techniques to predict ultraviolet (UV) radiation and noise levels during welding operations, with a focus on enhancing worker safety in the Indian foundry sector.
Problem: The study addressed the challenge of assessing the actual exposure of workers to UV radiation and noise in welding operations, especially in the context of evaluating compliance with safety standards in developing countries where adherence to these standards is often inadequate.
Data: The data used in the study included measurements of UV radiation and noise levels collected from the welding of a ferrous alloy in three different foundries located in Agra, India.
Methods_Techniques: Five different machine learning algorithms were applied to analyze the data and predict the levels of UV radiation and noise. These algorithms were then evaluated to compare their performance relative to safety standards.
Results: The study found that the Support Vector Machine (SVM) regression algorithm performed best for predicting UV radiation levels, with a Root Mean Square Error (RMSE) of 356.93, whereas the Random Forest algorithm was most effective for noise level prediction, achieving an RMSE of 11.4. These results demonstrate the utility of these algorithms in predicting exposure levels in welding operations.

Objectives: The main purpose of this study is to develop a predictive model using Artificial Neural Networks (ANNs) to forecast the health risks associated with whole-body vibration (WBV) exposure among mining vehicle operators under various operational conditions.
Problem: The study addresses the challenge of prolonged WBV exposure in mining operations, which is linked to adverse health effects such as musculoskeletal disorders, including chronic low back pain and lumbar disc herniation.
Data: The data used in the study includes vibration data collected from tippers during routine operations at an opencast mine in central India. The dataset contains various operational factors such as haul road type, operator weight, speed, and payload.
Methods_Techniques: The methods used in the study include the development of an ANN model with a Multilayer Perceptron (MLP) architecture. The model predicts the magnitude of vibration exposure, utilizing backpropagation to adjust neuron connection weights and minimize output prediction errors. The data was split with 70% used for training, and the remaining 30% for testing and validation.
Results: The study found that the ANN model showed an excellent correlation between predicted and actual frequency weighted root mean square acceleration (awrms), with correlation coefficients of 97.58% for the training stage and 97.4% for the testing stage, indicating the model’s high predictive accuracy in assessing health risks associated with WBV in mining vehicle operations.

Objectives: The main purpose of this study is to explore the use of a digital twin technology to transform warehouse management and operational efficiency in engineer-to-order manufacturing environments, specifically companies creating prefabricated building components.
Problem: The study addresses the challenges of highly customized product workflows and complex operations in engineer-to-order manufacturing, focusing on outdoor warehouse optimization and worker safety.
Data: The research utilizes in-depth analysis of the warehouse operations at Focchi S.p.A., a leader in manufacturing high-tech prefabricated building envelopes.
Methods_Techniques: The study outlines a methodology that integrates Internet of Things (IoT) devices, Building Information Modeling (BIM), and artificial intelligence to design and develop a digital twin. The methodology incorporates gathering and analyzing user requirements and designing for stakeholder interactions in the warehouse environment.
Results: Although preliminary testing results are not yet provided, the study identifies the potential of a BIM-, IoT-, and AI-integrated digital twin to streamline communication, enhance decision-making processes, and improve safety protocols in engineer-to-order manufacturing warehouses. The digital twin is recognized as a promising tool for increasing operational efficiency and safety, offering significant competitive advantages in the manufacturing industry.

Objectives: The study aimed to develop a privacy-preserving system that tracks and assesses the posture of assembly/disassembly line workers using artificial intelligence, aligning with the human-centric principles of the upcoming Industry 5.0 revolution.
Problem: The study addresses the problem of back pain among workers, which results in significant economic costs due to lost work days and healthcare expenses, while also needing to respect worker privacy and autonomy.
Data: The system utilizes inertial data recorded by a smartwatch and Laser Imaging Detection and Ranging (LiDAR) data to monitor worker postures, providing a basis for the assessment compliant with the ISO 11226 European standard.
Methods_Techniques: The study used a combination of inertial measurement data from a smartwatch and LiDAR technology. This approach evaluates upper-body (dominant arm, shoulder, and trunk) and lower-body (legs) postures without compromising the worker's privacy or revealing their identity.
Results: The system demonstrated high effectiveness, recognizing worker postures with a mean accuracy close to 98%. This capability indicates potential to improve worker health by identifying poor posture and reducing the risk of musculoskeletal disorders, in line with Industry 5.0's focus on worker well-being and rights protection.

Objectives: The main purpose of the study was to develop a novel knowledge graph for industrial safety (ISKG) with HAZOP as the carrier, aimed at reusing and unlocking the value of Industrial Safety Knowledge (ISK) and optimizing HAZOP processes.
Problem: The challenge addressed was the insufficient exploitation of the vast storehouse of Industrial Safety Knowledge (ISK) contained in HAZOP reports across different industrial processes, which had not been thoroughly harnessed due to varying expressions and standardization issues.
Data: The study used data from HAZOP reports of various industrial processes, focusing particularly on the indirect coal liquefaction process as a case study.
Methods_Techniques: The study employed a combination of deep learning and data science to create a novel and reliable information extraction model that effectively mines ISK from HAZOP reports. Additionally, a general ISK standardization framework was developed to integrate and uniformly represent this knowledge.
Results: The main findings include the successful creation of ISK triples and their storage within the Neo4j graph database. The development of ISKG not only optimizes HAZOP procedures but also enhances understanding and prevention awareness, demonstrating the significant potential of merging data science with engineering design to improve system security and ISK utilization.

Objectives: The main purpose of the study was to identify risk factors for occupational accidents in the construction industry and to examine the impacts of these factors using Bayesian networks (BNs), aiming to enhance prediction accuracy and reduce repetitive patterns in accident data for better classification analysis.
Problem: The construction industry is experiencing a rise in occupational accidents due to technological advancements, inadequate workplace safety procedures, and untrained workers, necessitating improved methods for predicting and managing these risks.
Data: The study utilized a dataset from an international construction firm, which included data on occupational accidents that were preprocessed for analysis.
Methods_Techniques: The research involved preprocessing the occupational accident data, conducting univariate frequency and cross-tabulation analysis, and leveraging Bayesian networks (BNs) to capture the conditional dependencies between various risk factors and their effects on occupational accidents.
Results: The findings revealed that certain occupational accident scenarios could be predicted with high accuracy using Bayesian networks and other machine learning methods. Moreover, the study evaluated the accuracy and efficacy of the Bayesian network model in handling classified accident data.

Objectives: The main purpose of the study was to improve safety at construction sites by using an image semantic segmentation method based on Deep Learning (DL) to monitor the fall risk of construction workers near building elevator shafts.
Problem: The study addressed the challenge of frequent construction accidents, particularly the risks posed by unprotected elevator shafts, despite existing safety regulations and the use of personal protection devices by workers.
Data: The data used in this study included laboratory results and in-situ testing results related to the application of the Deep Learning-based image semantic segmentation method.
Methods_Techniques: The study applied an image semantic segmentation method using Deep Learning techniques to monitor the behavior and safety of construction workers, particularly in the vicinity of elevator shafts.
Results: The results showed that the Recall and Precision during training in the laboratory and the Cleanness and Correctness obtained on site surpassed the 95% performance criteria, indicating the effectiveness of the method in monitoring and preventing accidental falls at construction sites.

Objectives: The main purpose of the study was to develop intellectual ability in manufacturing processes and to predict and improve occupational health and safety in the fireworks industry.
Problem: The study addressed the problem of frequent and serious accidents in the fireworks industry, which is a major threat and the leading cause of death, requiring the analysis of various influential factors.
Data: The study utilized a real dataset containing various influential factors linked to fireworks incidents, including chemicals, facilities, transport, temperature, friction, etc.
Methods_Techniques: The study applied data mining solutions and employed the Decision Tree classifier as a method to forecast important factors influencing human health and safety in fireworks manufacturing environments.
Results: The findings indicated that the Decision Tree classifier technique could effectively predict the risk factors in the fireworks industry regarding safety measures, contributing to improving the industry's performance.

Objectives: The main purpose of this study was to explore the efficacy of using smartphone sound level meter applications (apps), specifically the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health (NIOSH) app, as an alternative to traditional noise measurement devices for assessing noise levels in various everyday environments.
Problem: The challenge addressed was the potential utility and accuracy of smartphone apps in measuring noise exposures in non-traditional and non-occupational settings, where traditional occupational noise exposures are well understood but less is known about these newer environments.
Data: The study involved noise measurements obtained from an office, coffee shop, commuter train, restaurant, and spin class settings using both a traditional noise dosimeter and a smartphone equipped with the NIOSH sound level meter app.
Methods_Techniques: The study compared noise level measurements from a conventional noise dosimeter and a smartphone running the NIOSH sound level meter app in various real-world environments to test the accuracy of the smartphone app.
Results: Noise levels across studied settings ranged between 47.7 dBA and 101.7 dBA, with mean differences in sound level measurements between devices staying below 2.0 dBA in environments like commuter trains, restaurants, and spin classes. The findings indicated that the NIOSH app could be used effectively as a screening tool in some settings, particularly where noise levels are stable and exceed 75 dBA. These insights are relevant as wearable technologies with internal microphones start to measure sound levels, which might encounter similar issues to those identified with smartphones without external calibrated microphones.

Objectives: The main purpose of this study was to propose a feature-optimized predictive model for forecasting the severity of occupational injuries using machine learning techniques.
Problem: The challenge addressed in the study was the need for a predictive analysis tool to forecast the severity of occupational injuries, improving workplace safety measures and preventive strategies.
Data: The data utilized in this study consisted of 66,405 occupational injury records sourced from a public database managed by OSHA (Occupational Safety and Health Administration).
Methods_Techniques: The study applied five different machine learning models for predictive analysis: Support Vector Machine, K-Nearest Neighbors, Naïve Bayes, Decision Tree, and Random Forest. Feature optimization and hyperparameter tuning were also employed to enhance the model's performance.
Results: The main findings indicated that the Random Forest model outperformed the others with the highest accuracy and F1-score. It was particularly effective after feature optimization and hyperparameter tuning, significantly improving the prediction accuracy by 0.5%, achieving 0.895 in hospitalization predictions and 0.954 in amputation predictions. The three most critical features identified were ‘nature of injury’, ‘type of event’, and ‘affected body part’.

Objectives: The main purpose of the study was to explore visual searching strategies through eye-tracking scan patterns to enhance construction safety inspection.
Problem: The challenge addressed was the lack of research into scan patterns of hazard recognition in the construction industry and how these patterns can be utilized for better safety management.
Data: The data used in this study included eye-tracking scanpaths collected from 47 participants who were identifying hazards in a simulated construction site environment.
Methods_Techniques: The study used a portable eye-tracking device to collect scanning data. Artificial intelligence was employed to quantitatively define areas of interest (AOIs) based on fixation data from participants. The research then compared searching strategies between participants who successfully recognized hazards and those who did not.
Results: The findings revealed that participants who effectively recognized hazards followed similar and distinct searching patterns compared to those who failed to recognize hazards. This indicates that successful hazard detection involves specific visual scanning strategies.

Objectives: The main purpose of this study was to correlate EEG signal patterns with different types of construction hazards and to develop an effective EEG classifier using virtual reality experiments to aid in real-time hazard identification on construction sites.
Problem: The primary challenge addressed was the unproven capacity of EEG (electroencephalogram) signals for the classification of multiple hazard types, which is critical for enhancing workers' safety by implementing real-time hazard identification in the construction industry.
Data: The data used in this study included EEG signals collected from subjects wearing wearable EEG and virtual reality devices. These subjects were exposed to various simulated construction hazards such as falls and slips/trips in a VR environment.
Methods_Techniques: A variety of methods were employed including the extraction of two types of EEG features (time-domain/frequency-domain features and cognitive features), and the use of eighteen advanced machine learning algorithms to develop the EEG classifier. Experiments were conducted within a VR setting to simulate real-life hazard conditions and collect EEG data.
Results: The study initially found that the LightGBM classifier reached a 70.1% accuracy using cognitive features for 7-class classification. Performance was improved through relabeling the input data and implementing three new strategies, ultimately achieving an 82.3% accuracy with a two-step ensemble classification approach. This demonstrates the feasibility of using wearable EEG, VR, and machine learning to distinguish between different jobsite hazards and suggests methods to enhance the accuracy of multi-class hazard classification.

Data: The data used in the study include images captured from mobile devices, unmanned aerial vehicles, wearable sensors, and building information modeling (BIM).
Methods_Techniques: AI, machine learning, and deep learning systems were used to analyze the data. Specific techniques include scanning jobsite images for safety hazards, correlating images with accident records, identifying unsafe worker behavior, and tracking real-time interactions on construction sites.
Results: The study found that AI-based algorithms effectively monitor safety hazards, identify risks, and suggest preventive measures. It also discussed using AI to execute Shock and Arc Flash Risk Assessment Procedure templates and addressed potential ethical issues from worker perspectives.

Objectives: The main purpose of this study was to compare the focus on construction safety and health hazard awareness between academic literature and laypeople's discussions on Weibo.
Problem: The study addresses the discrepancy in the themes and focal points between academia and the general public concerning construction hazard awareness.
Data: The data consisted of 11,829 Weibo microposts related to construction safety and health hazard awareness and 769 academic articles indexed in Web of Science (WoS) from 1900 to 2021.
Methods_Techniques: The study involved a comparative analysis of the topics discussed in Weibo microposts and academic articles to determine differing priorities and approaches between laypeople and researchers.
Results: The findings revealed that while academic circles concentrated on advanced technological applications like artificial intelligence for hazard identification and risk management, lay discussions rarely touched on these high-tech solutions and instead focused on more immediate and practical concerns like collapse, earthquakes, and safety management.

Objectives: The study aimed to understand why construction workers fail to effectively identify and manage safety hazards during hazard recognition and management efforts, and to develop evidence-based interventions to improve hazard identification and management performance in the construction industry.
Problem: The construction industry is recognized as one of the most hazardous sectors globally, with a significant problem of workers failing to recognize and manage safety hazards adequately.
Data: The study utilized eye-tracking technology to collect data on workers' examination patterns of their work environments, along with stereoscopic visual data captured from real construction sites for developing mixed reality training environments.
Methods_Techniques: The research involved analyzing hazard recognition as a visual search task using eye-tracking technology, developing an immersive hyper-realistic mixed reality training environment, and creating an AI-based system that uses wearable camera footage to detect hazardous conditions in real-time.
Results: The findings showed that the mixed reality training environment significantly improved hazard identification and management performance among 56 tested participants. The AI-based detection system achieved 93% accuracy in recognizing workers’ proximity to hazards in both indoor and outdoor construction settings.

Objectives: The main purpose of this study was to assess and minimize the explosion risk of corn dust by determining the minimum ignition temperature (MIT) under various conditions, and to develop predictive models for MIT using polynomial surface fitting and artificial neural networks (ANN).
Problem: Corn dust is a common and highly combustible substance in the food manufacturing industry that poses significant safety hazards, including the risk of explosions in ignition-sensitive environments.
Data: The study used experimental data obtained by analyzing the ignition of corn dust clouds in a Godbert Greenwald furnace, under different dispersion pressures and concentrations of corn dust.
Methods_Techniques: The study employed the following methods: 1. Determining the MIT for corn dust clouds under varying conditions using experimental setups. 2. Polynomial surface fitting to statistically forecast the MIT based on the impacts of concentration and dispersion pressure. 3. Utilization of artificial neural networks (ANN) as predictive tools to model MIT for specific conditions of dispersion pressures and concentrations. 4. Selection of the most appropriate polynomial model was based on the minimum value of the Bayesian Information Criterion (BIC).
Results: Key findings include: 1. The MIT rises with a decrease in particle size and falls with increase in dispersion pressure and concentration until a critical value known as the optimal value for ignition. 2. Predictive results from the ANN were in good agreement with the polynomial surface fit and close to results obtained in previous research by Kasalova and Balog. 3. Several ANN models were trained using different numbers of neurons and transfer functions, showing high R-values (approximate to 1.0) in training, validation, and testing phases, which indicates high accuracy in the predictive capacity of the ANN model.

Objectives: The main purpose of the study was to propose and test a new clustering algorithm called growing self-organizing map-based genetic K-means (GSGKM) combined with Tolerance Rough Set Approach (TRSA) to enhance accident analysis and prevention in workplaces.
Problem: The study addressed the challenge of analyzing high-dimensional accident data, which is typically complex due to issues like slow convergence and local minima problems that hinder efficient decision-making.
Data: The data used included accident records from an integrated steel plant for a case study, and four benchmark datasets from the University of California, Irvine (UCI) machine learning repository for a comparative study.
Methods_Techniques: The proposed methodology involved the use of the GSGKM algorithm to classify accident data into an optimal number of clusters. Subsequently, the TRSA was applied on each cluster to extract meaningful accident patterns.
Results: The study found that the proposed GSGKM methodology yielded the highest clustering accuracy compared to other state-of-the-art methods. Four clusters were identified with a total of 16 clear accident patterns or rules extracted using TRSA. The analysis also pointed out that company employees are more prone to accidents compared to contractors, and behavioral issues were the most determinant factor for injuries at work. The methodology proved effective for decision-making across various industries.

Objectives: The main purpose of this study was to propose a correlation-based approach for mobile scaffold safety monitoring and detecting worker's unsafe behaviors in the construction industry.
Problem: The problem addressed in this study is the high occurrence of deaths from falls from height and scaffolding-related accidents in the construction industry, compounded by the impracticality and infeasibility of current safety monitoring practices due to the dynamic nature of construction sites.
Data: The study utilized a data set consisting of real scenarios from construction sites to test the proposed approach.
Methods_Techniques: The study applied a deep neural network, specifically the Mask R-CNN, enhanced with an object correlation detection (OCD) module. This combination was used for the classification and segmentation of worker tasks, and for identifying unsafe behaviors, dividing worker safety into two categories: safe (class-1) and unsafe (class-2) behavior.
Results: The main findings revealed that the system achieved 85% precision and 97% recall for detecting safe behaviors, and 91% precision and 65% recall for detecting unsafe behaviors, with an overall accuracy of 86%. This confirms the effectiveness of the Mask R-CNN-based OCD module in detecting unsafe behaviors in a construction environment.

Objectives: The main purpose of the study was to develop an automated preprocessing model that can identify the best scenario for predicting the severity of construction accidents.
Problem: The challenge addressed is the lack of focus on preprocessing pipelines in existing studies on predicting accident severity in construction, which have mainly concentrated on selecting machine learning methods.
Data: The abstract does not specify the exact data used; however, it implicitly refers to construction accident data involving attributes like year, cause material, age, past accidents, experience, and salary.
Methods_Techniques: The study implemented a scenario-basis automated preprocessing model that tested various combinations of methods including handling missing data, data binning, outlier consideration, Min-Max-Scaler, one-hot encoding, and data resampling with random oversampling.
Results: The highest performing scenario did not remove missing data, did not apply data binning, considered outliers, applied Min-Max-Scaler and one-hot encoding, and used random oversampling, achieving an F1-score of 0.6092. Permutation importance by XGBoost revealed the most influential attributes to be year, cause material, age, past accidents, experience, and salary.

Objectives: The main goal of the study was to automate the identification of unsafe behaviors in construction sites using machine learning and computer vision technologies in order to facilitate early warnings and intervene promptly in dangerous tasks during hoisting operations in prefabricated building projects.
Problem: The study addresses the frequent occurrence of safety accidents in the construction industry, primarily caused by the unsafe behavior of workers.
Data: The study utilized a large amount of image data collected from construction sites for processing and analysis.
Methods_Techniques: The research applied computer vision technology coupled with machine learning methods to identify unsafe behaviors automatically and provide early warnings concerning the safety risks associated with tower crane operations in construction sites.
Results: The study resulted in the development of a system capable of providing timely warnings and interventions during the hoisting operations of prefabricated components, thus potentially reducing the occurrence of accidents by suspending hazardous tasks based on the warning results.

Objectives: The main purpose of the study was to use Artificial Intelligence (AI) methods to identify patterns in Occupational Health Protection (OHP) records to enhance occupational risk prevention and support the design of functional work ability models in the automotive industry.
Problem: The study addressed the challenge of understanding the effectiveness of Occupational Health Protection in reducing functional ability loss due to various working conditions in the automotive industry and how these protections are designated for multiple body parts.
Data: The data comprised a database of 383 OHP profiles from employees in the automotive industry, focusing on records against physical working conditions over two years.
Methods_Techniques: Artificial Intelligence (AI) methods, particularly Association Rules (ARs) and Natural Language Processing (NLP) techniques, were used to analyze the data and extract patterns. The ARs were then filtered using three metrics: support, confidence, and lift.
Results: The study discovered 54 significant association rules, indicating patterns in the allocation of protection profiles to at least two body parts simultaneously with a higher distribution observed in special projects. These findings can be used to design multi-site body parts functional work ability loss models, model organizational capacity to retain workers, and prevent work-related musculoskeletal symptoms.

Objectives: The main purpose of the study is to utilize machine learning for automatically labeling accident narratives to facilitate easier analysis and improve occupational health and safety strategies.
Problem: The challenge addressed is the difficulty in analyzing accident data due to its textual format, which complicates extracting actionable insights.
Data: The data used in the study includes a large dataset of textual accident narratives collected from the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), focusing on narratives where workers were injured. Additional datasets from the construction and mining and metals industries were also analyzed.
Methods_Techniques: The study applied word embeddings-based text mining, which showed excellent performance compared to previous methods. Machine learning models were used to classify each record across five dimensions: body part(s) injured, the source of the injury, the type of event causing the injury, hospitalization occurrences, and amputation occurrences. The models were then tested for generalizability through transfer learning on other industry datasets.
Results: The primary result was the effective classification of accident narratives across specified dimensions, improving the organization's capability to quickly and accurately analyze textual data. This facilitates better understanding and prevention of workplace accidents.

Objectives: The main purpose of this study was to analyze the impact of various contributing factors on injuries sustained by roofing contractors in the construction industry, using data mining techniques.
Problem: Roofing contractors in the construction industry are highly vulnerable to occupational hazards, particularly falls from height, which poses a significant risk of injuries.
Data: The study analyzed over 600 incidents reported in the Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) database, which included both fatal and nonfatal accident reports.
Methods_Techniques: The study employed the random forest data mining technique to identify and analyze the factors contributing to roofers' injuries.
Results: The analysis revealed that the most critical factor for predicting the nature of injury was the injured body part, followed by the source of injury. These findings can aid managers, policymakers, and safety professionals in mitigating the frequency and severity of roofing accidents.

Objectives: The main purpose of this study was to demonstrate the application of machine learning techniques using probabilistic gradient boosted decision trees to model raw sensor readings for occupational exposure assessments, completely eliminating the need for laboratory calibration. The study aimed to use these models to generate probabilistic hazard maps and improve decision-making in industrial settings using the American Industrial Hygiene Association (AIHA) exposure ratings.
Problem: The problem addressed in this study is the traditional approach in occupational exposure assessments that often relies on small sample sizes and low spatial and temporal resolution. These methods likely underestimate true exposures and their variability while failing to characterize exposures at all in unsampled areas.
Data: The data used in this study came from carbon monoxide sensors, which were deployed in a heavy equipment manufacturing facility over a period of eight months, from August 2017 to March 2018.
Methods_Techniques: The study employed machine learning with probabilistic gradient boosted decision trees (GBDT) to accurately model raw sensor readings against reference data. This method allowed the researchers to bypass the need for traditional laboratory calibration and to produce fully modeled prediction distributions for each measurement.
Results: The main findings of the study include the successful elimination of the need for laboratory calibration of sensors through the application of machine learning models. These models could generate probabilistic hazard maps, which provide a visual tool for assessing facility-wide exposures. Furthermore, the results indicated the potential of machine learning to use AIHA exposure ratings effectively in decision-making processes and to prevent misclassification of exposures that might occur with traditional models based on mean or point predictions.

Objectives: The main purpose of this study is to propose an effective solution that integrates Environmental, Health, and Safety (EHS) and Asset Integrity/Performance Management (AIM/APM) with Pipeline Safety Management System (PSMS) data into a comprehensive Operational Risk Management (ORM) framework that enhances real-time, risk-based decision-making and profitability analysis.
Problem: The study addresses the current inefficiencies in EHS and AIM/APM platforms, specifically their failure to aggregate data from various PSMS workflows into a unified database that supports real-time, risk-based analyses and impacts on profitability.
Data: The data integration proposed in the study involves reframing EHS and AIM/APM in the context of ORM by normalizing performance and process-related parameters, along with linking to data historians like OSIsoft PI.
Methods_Techniques: The methods proposed include categorizing, prioritizing, and risk-ranking incidents by economic impact, incorporating predictive analytics to enhance data visibility and voice of equipment, and applying best practice standards such as API 754 for Process Safety Performance Indicators. The solution also involves setting up a one-stop system that merges highly interlinked systems of EHS, compliance, and enterprise risk management in one framework.
Results: The proposed solution facilitates holistic, enterprise-wide visibility and accountability, ensuring effective Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG) program effectiveness and sustainability. This is achieved through a highly configurable user interface that allows for trending of key performance indicators (KPIs), incident investigation, reporting, and decision support for failure modes.

Objectives: The main purpose of this study was to evaluate the robustness of the NIOCCS algorithm when provided with low-quality inputs and assess how variations in input quality impact the accuracy of job exposure estimates in a large job-exposure matrix for noise.
Problem: The challenge addressed was the lack of external validation of the NIOCCS algorithm's performance in assigning accurate industry and occupational codes when faced with varying qualities of free-text inputs.
Data: The data used included over 700,000 noise measurements from the NoiseJEM, alongside differentially prepared free-text descriptions of industries and job titles to evaluate the NIOCCS algorithm's performance.
Methods_Techniques: The study involved creating three distinct files with varying levels of refined inputs: (1) “raw” industries and job titles (N1), (2) “refined” industries and “raw” job titles (N2), and (3) “refined” industries and job titles (N3), and then processing these through NIOCCS. The output codes were compared using descriptive statistics to assess misclassification and discordance rates against the original, unaltered dataset (N0).
Results: The findings revealed discordance rates of 53.6% for N1, 42.3% for N2, and 5.0% for N3 when compared to N0, showcasing that input refinement markedly improves coding accuracy. N2 provided the most accurate noise exposure estimates across major SOC groups with minimal bias, but further refinement in N3 showed little improvement in performance. The study also noted variation in classification efficacy over time, especially before 1985, emphasizing the influence of input quality on machine learning algorithm outcomes.

Objectives: The main purpose of the study was to apply Big Data science, specifically tools and techniques from process mining, to the safety domain in order to derive novel insights and improve visualization of safety process data.
Problem: Despite the collection of vast amounts of data in asset-intensive industries, the high accident statistics remain unchanged because the data often does not provide actionable insights.
Data: The study used process execution data from a Permit to Work system within an Australian energy company.
Methods_Techniques: Process mining methods were applied to analyze the process execution data, aiming to understand the complexity of the Permit to Work process, examine conformance and performance issues, and identify resources associated with these issues.
Results: The analysis revealed the complexity of the Permit to Work process, identified specific conformance and performance issues, and disclosed changes in the frequency of these issues over time. These insights suggest a need to simplify the system, offering a new perspective that could serve as a catalyst for further research at the interface between Big Data science and safety management.

Objectives: The main purpose of the study was to explore how coupling Artificial Intelligence (AI) with the Internet of Things (IoT) can enhance hazard identification in the construction industry to overcome the limitations posed by human factors.
Problem: Despite various government frameworks aimed at reducing workplace accidents, about 25% of safety hazards still go unnoticed by construction workers, largely due to human factors such as physiological and psychological states, attention span, bias, and risk tolerance levels.
Data: The paper does not specify the exact data used but discusses workplace safety statistics from the Singapore WSH (Workplace Safety and Health) Council regarding fatal injuries in the construction industry during the first half of 2019.
Methods_Techniques: The study suggests the integration of AI with IoT as a method to improve hazard identification at construction sites, though specific techniques and processes of implementation are not detailed in the abstract.
Results: The abstract does not provide specific outcomes or results from the implementation of AI and IoT technologies in hazard identification, focusing instead on the potential of such technologies to address the problem.

Objectives: The main purpose of this study was to develop a meta-learning framework called MetaInjury to enhance the ability to share risk knowledge and predict the risk of work-related injuries in various construction industry accidents, especially when dealing with small sample data of new accident types.
Problem: The challenge addressed was the limited availability of specific accident injury data, which complicates obtaining risk knowledge and establishing effective accident consequence prediction models in the construction industry.
Data: The study utilized accident injury records and engaged in modeling based on these records to predict occupational risks in the construction industry.
Methods_Techniques: The MetaInjury framework uses a process to first calculate the document vector of an accident description and determine its proximity to vectors in a Meta-knowledge database to identify similar accident types. It then correlates meta-features with appropriate machine learning algorithms to recommend accident prediction algorithms.
Results: The results demonstrated that the MetaInjury framework effectively supports the prevention of small sample accidents and injury reduction in the construction industry by enabling safety managers to share important accident risk factors and assessment rules, and predict specific small sample accident consequences using the recommended algorithms.

Objectives: The main purpose of this study was to evaluate and analyze the health risk of occupational exposure to toxic chemicals in coal mines, using a deep learning algorithm and mathematical model.
Problem: The study addressed the challenge of assessing the risk from toxic substances in the working environment of coal mines, owing to the rise in mining activities in China and associated safety and health risks.
Data: The study used data collected from the working environment and employees of four different areas within a coal mine in Shanxi Province. This included samples of gases present in the working areas.
Methods_Techniques: The researchers employed deep learning algorithms coupled with mathematical evaluation models and a single factor evaluation grade technique to compute the lung condition of mine workers and the concentration of harmful gases, and ultimately derive a risk index for the area.
Results: The findings indicate that when the coal cutting amount increases, the induced airflow velocity in chutes and guide chutes also increases significantly (54% and 53%, respectively). This increase correlates with higher concentrations of harmful substances in the environment. The study validates the effectiveness and accuracy of the deep learning mathematical model in assessing health risks linked to toxic chemicals in coal mines, emphasizing its importance for the safety management of mine workers.

Objectives: The main purpose of the study was to propose a perception module using end-to-end deep learning and visual SLAM for effective and efficient object recognition and navigation applied specifically to improve occupational safety in the construction industry.
Problem: Existing methods in occupational safety that utilize conventional machine learning with stationary cameras face challenges such as perceptual aliasing, occlusion, changes due to seasonal variations and illumination, and significant viewpoint changes, which reduce their effectiveness and reliability in the construction industry.
Data: The data used included real-world settings in the construction industry to test the proposed deep learning models and visual SLAM strategies.
Methods_Techniques: The study implemented various deep learning frameworks and visual navigation strategies, along with evaluation metrics like model speed, accuracy, complexity, precision, recall, P-R curve, and F1 score, to select the best model for deployment on a mobile robot. The YOLOv3 algorithm was specifically evaluated, and the Google Cartographer SLAM was used for laser SLAM assessments.
Results: The YOLOv3 demonstrated a favorable balance between performance metrics with a mean average precision of 57.9% and an ability to process 45 frames per second on NVIDIA Jetson TX2, making it suitable for real-time detection and deployment on mobile robots. The Google Cartographer SLAM showed the lowest RMSE, indicating reliable performance in terms of localization and mapping, and acceptable processing times. The perception module was proven to effectively detect construction workers not using hard hats under various site conditions and could enhance safety inspection and supervision in line with OSHA standards.

Objectives: The main purpose of the study was to design a system that aids in individual environmental risk assessment and long-term risk management within the context of Industry 4.0.
Problem: The challenge addressed was the need for a reliable system to monitor and manage workers' exposure to hazardous agents in the workplace, such as dust, noise, ultraviolet radiation, poor lighting, and inappropriate temperature and humidity.
Data: Data for this study was collected using IoT devices that monitored various hazardous agents in the workplace.
Methods_Techniques: The study implemented a system comprising a monitoring device and a server. It involved employee registration, securing messages from monitoring devices, displaying exposure information, and triggering alarms based on legislative and standard limits. The system was tested in a controlled environment.
Results: The results from the controlled environment tests are discussed in the paper. The system, though still under development, successfully monitored and reported on hazardous exposures, and future enhancements will include a smartphone app for employee use and artificial intelligence for data analysis and long-term planning.

Objectives: The main purpose of this study was to propose and validate a new method for predicting single-worker severity levels using site images and video clips to enhance frequency and accuracy of safety monitoring on construction sites.
Problem: The challenge addressed was the time-consuming and costly nature of omnipresent safety monitoring on construction sites, despite the critical importance of risk analysis for long-term safety enhancements.
Data: The study utilized a challenging image dataset, which included images of construction workers annotated with ground truth severity level annotations.
Methods_Techniques: The researchers developed efficient computer vision models for risk analysis, implementing a multitask recognition model that processes objects, activity, and keypoints from visual data simultaneously. This included a spatio-temporal graph neural network for improving worker activity recognition through the use of per-frame activity, tool and material bounding boxes, and worker poses. Finally, a trained classifier was used for predicting severity levels.
Results: The prediction model demonstrated 85.7% cross-validation accuracy for bricklaying tasks and 86.6% cross-validation accuracy for plastering tasks, showcasing significant potential for real-time worker safety detection and severity assessment in construction environments.

Objectives: The study aimed to assess the health risks of occupational exposure to 1,3-butadiene vapors in a petrochemical industry in Iran.
Problem: The primary problem addressed is the potential health risks, including carcinogenic effects, posed by exposure to 1,3-butadiene among workers in the petrochemical industry.
Data: The study involved 150 samples collected from the respiratory air of 50 workers in a petrochemical industry that produces copolymer ABS (acrylonitrile, butadiene, styrene) in Iran during 2018.
Methods_Techniques: The study utilized the NIOSH 1024 method for sampling, using coconut-activated charcoal adsorbent tubes and gas chromatography-flame ionization detection (GC-FID) for analysis. It assessed exposure through an occupational exposure index, corrected for work hours, and applied a quantitative risk assessment method involving the hazard quotient (HQ) index for health risk calculations.
Results: Results indicated that the mean respiratory exposure to 1,3-butadiene was below the occupational limit, with variations seen across workstations. Safety and fire-fighting station workers showed the highest exposure levels. Notably, 60% of workers faced unacceptable health risks (HQ > 1.0). The study highlighted the necessity of improved ventilation and control systems to reduce exposure and associated health risks.

Objectives: The main purpose of this study was to emphasize the importance of integrating the spatial dimension into individual and continuous occupational risk exposure monitoring within the context of Industry 4.0.
Problem: The challenge addressed was the lack of consideration for spatial data in existing big data-based solutions for occupational risk management, which have become increasingly important with the rise of safety 4.0 and industry 4.0 technologies.
Data: The study utilized data collected through IoT (Internet of Things) and wearable devices, characteristic of Industry 4.0, to gather occupational health and safety (OHS) risk exposure information.
Methods_Techniques: The research presented a typical architecture of an integrated system that leverages IoT and spatial big data technologies. This system collects, stores, analyzes, and visualizes the data to facilitate improved monitoring and understanding of OHS risks.
Results: The main findings highlighted the effectiveness of the proposed architecture in enhancing the monitoring, interpretation, and understanding of OHS-related issues by integrating spatial data handling and visualization capabilities.

Objectives: The main purpose of the study was to assess the feasibility of using artificial intelligence (AI) and deep learning techniques to automate the compliance of personal protective equipment (PPE) at workplaces.
Problem: The challenge addressed was the issue of employee compliance and proper use of PPE, despite companies being able to provide the necessary equipment.
Data: The abstract does not specify the exact data used for the study, but it implies the use of image or video data for the application of AI techniques in detecting PPE usage.
Methods_Techniques: The study applied the YOLOv5 (You Only Look Once version 5) deep learning algorithm to detect various types of head-mounted PPE.
Results: The YOLOv5 algorithm achieved high precision, with an average score of 0.857, in detecting head-mounted PPE, indicating a strong potential for future applications of AI tools in enhancing PPE compliance and workplace safety.

Objectives: The main purpose of this study was to improve the safety of workers in shared workspaces by enhancing the early detection of humans through machine learning, specifically in environments where humans and robots coexist.
Problem: The study addressed the challenge of ensuring the reliability and robustness of machine learning systems that detect humans in shared workspaces, which is crucial for preventing downtime or system stoppages due to the close proximity of humans and robots.
Data: The researchers created their own dataset for the experiment, which included images of humans wearing different types of clothing to train the detection models.
Methods_Techniques: The study applied advanced machine learning techniques, specifically evaluating the performance of Faster R-CNN and SSD, which are state-of-the-art object detection models. The evaluations were conducted using two different camera viewpoints to assess the effectiveness of these techniques in detecting humans in a workspace shared with robots.
Results: The paper details the experimental setup and discusses the requirements necessary for validating the safety of such detection systems, implying the effectiveness and potential industrial application of the evaluated models, although specific performance results aren't mentioned in the abstract.

Objectives: The main purpose of this study is to explore the application of machine learning in overcoming subjectivity and bias in risk ranking decision-making processes related to industrial accidents, as part of addressing the Fourth Industrial Revolution (IR 4.0) trends.
Problem: The study addresses Malaysia's lag behind Singapore in adopting AI innovations within ASEAN countries, and the challenges specific to applying machine learning in accident risk analysis in Malaysian industries.
Data: The study relies on a review of existing literature pertaining to machine learning applications, supplemented by data from industrial and governmental agencies such as the Department of Occupational Safety and Health (DOSH) Malaysia.
Methods_Techniques: The study employs a literature review methodology, focusing on evaluating existing machine learning features for their feasibility in industrial accident analysis. It particularly assesses the use of supervised machine learning in this context.
Results: The findings highlight the necessity of a publicly accessible large database from industries and agencies to develop effective algorithms that improve accident risk analysis and safety decision-making. The study also notes existing challenges in harnessing supervised machine learning for these purposes in Malaysia.

Objectives: The main goal of this study was to develop a systematic strategy using deep learning models to monitor the use of hard hats at construction sites in real-time, enhancing occupational health and safety practices in the industry.
Problem: The study addresses the major issue of non-compliance with safety helmet usage at construction sites, which often leads to serious injuries or fatalities due to falling objects. This problem is exacerbated by the difficulty in maintaining round-the-clock human monitoring of safety practices.
Data: The study utilized a dataset comprising 7063 images to train and evaluate the deep learning models.
Methods_Techniques: The research implemented various models of the YOLOV5 architecture—specifically YOLOV5n, YOLOv5s, YOLOv5m, YOLOv5l, and YOLOv5x—within the PyTorch framework to detect whether construction workers are wearing hard hats.
Results: The findings revealed that the YOLOV5x model performed the best, achieving a high mean Average Precision (mAP) of 95.8%, while the YOLOV5n model was the fastest, processing images at 70.4 frames per second (FPS). These results demonstrate the feasibility of using this technology to monitor hard hat usage effectively at construction sites.

Objectives: The main goal of the study is to improve the analysis of occupational injuries in the construction industry using an attribute-based risk assessment model combined with a degree of risk assessment to enhance the understanding and management of safety hazards.
Problem: The study addresses the challenge of systematically analyzing risk factors and safety attributes in the dynamic environment of the construction industry, where occupational safety hazards are a major concern.
Data: The study utilizes data from a large collection of construction-related injury reports, which are classified according to risk factors and safety attributes outlined by the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health (NIOSH) and other safety standards.
Methods_Techniques: The methods applied include an attribute-based risk assessment model and a degree of risk assessment. Additionally, data mining techniques are used to analyze the data to reveal associations, visualizations, and correlation coefficients between risky activities and construction hazards.
Results: The results are expected to reveal key relationships between causes of safety hazards, critical safety attributes, and ergonomic characteristics. It also aims to understand the levels of injury and their relevant risk controls and preventions to benefit the construction industry.

Objectives: The study aims to explore the applications of artificial intelligence (AI) in the construction industry, examine the AI techniques being used, and identify both opportunities and challenges for AI integration in this field.
Problem: The construction industry faces significant issues such as cost and time overruns, health and safety concerns, productivity and labor shortages. Additionally, it is one of the least digitized industries, making it difficult to address these problems effectively.
Data: The study involved a critical review of existing literature on AI applications within the construction industry, focusing on areas such as activity monitoring, risk management, resource and waste optimization.
Methods_Techniques: The research method involved reviewing available literature to summarize the current state of AI applications in the construction industry and to identify the benefits and challenges associated with these applications.
Results: The findings reveal key AI applications pertinent to addressing specific challenges in the construction industry and outline a pathway for realizing the potential benefits of AI in enhancing efficiency, safety, and profitability in the sector. Opportunities and challenges of AI applications were also comprehensively presented.

Objectives: The main purpose of the study was to improve ergonomics and safety conditions in the workplace within the context of industry 4.0 by developing a technology that could cooperate with human operators and machines.
Problem: The specific challenge addressed was the vibration risk, a known cause of work-related pathologies in industrial settings.
Data: The study used vibration data collected using a wearable device designed to segment signals into time windows.
Methods_Techniques: The methods applied included the development of a wearable device for data collection and the implementation of a machine learning classifier to recognize worker activities and evaluate exposure to vibration risks.
Results: The experimental results indicated that the methodology was both feasible and effective in addressing the problem of vibration risks in the workplace.

Objectives: The main purpose of the study was to develop an artificial intelligence (AI)-based system using wearable sensors to assess the safety level of workers lifting loads, aiming to detect unsafe lifting practices and potentially reduce the risk of back injuries and musculoskeletal disorders.
Problem: The study addresses the significant issue of low back pain and injuries among workers who manually handle loads in workplaces such as warehousing, agriculture, and construction. These injuries are prevalent and largely occur due to the improper lifting of loads.
Data: The system utilized data collected by wearable sensors integrated into a reflective safety jacket, which included two barometric altimeters, a triaxial accelerometer, and a triaxial magnetometer.
Methods_Techniques: The developed system employed sensors to continuously monitor signals during workers' shifts. Data from the barometric altimeters were fused to detect load lifting events, and a neural classifier analyzed the accelerometer and magnetometer signals to assess whether the load lifting was performed safely.
Results: The system was tested on 30 workers, demonstrating high effectiveness with an accuracy rate of 95.6% in identifying whether the lifting tasks were performed safely.

Objectives: The main purpose of the study was to develop a system using wearable technology and machine learning to automatically identify the use time of hand-held vibrating tools in the workplace.
Problem: The study addressed the challenge of risk assessment related to exposure to vibrations affecting the hand-arm system in workplaces and aimed to improve methodologies for quantifying the effects on workers’ health.
Data: The study utilized data collected from a commercial smartwatch used in the operational environment where hand-held vibrating tools are employed.
Methods_Techniques: Machine learning techniques were applied to the data collected by the smartwatch to develop an automatic recognition system that can identify three types of machine families and a specific model within a single tool family.
Results: The system demonstrated high accuracy in recognizing different types of machine families and specific models within these families, suggesting its efficacy in assessing and managing occupational risks associated with the use of vibrating hand-held tools.

Objectives: The main purpose of the study was to implement data analytics and Machine Learning (ML) techniques in the construction safety sector to enhance workplace safety by predicting construction fatalities and understanding the severity of safety risks in projects.
Problem: The study addressed the high fatality rate in the construction industry and the need for project managers to understand and mitigate the risks associated with their projects.
Data: The study utilized a dataset comprising 4847 incident reports from the years 2015 to 2017, sourced from the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) database.
Methods_Techniques: The study employed data analytics to identify key attributes related to construction incidents, which were classified into Before Accident and After Accident categories. Machine Learning algorithms, specifically Random Forest (RF) and Decision Tree (DT), were then used to predict construction fatalities based on these attributes.

Objectives: The main purpose of this study was to assess the microbial contamination (specifically fungi and bacteria) in two coffee production facilities in Brazil.
Problem: Previous studies have documented respiratory abnormalities among workers in coffee roasting and packaging facilities, but there was limited understanding about the microbiological contamination in such environments.
Data: The study used samples collected from four main sources at the coffee production facilities: filtering respiratory protection devices (FRPD) worn by workers, settled dust, electrostatic dust cloths (EDC), and coffee beans.
Methods_Techniques: The study utilized a multi-approach protocol for sampling and subsequent analysis, including molecular detection of toxigenic fungal species and assessment of antifungal resistance.
Results: The study found the highest bacterial contamination in FRPDs from both facilities. There was also a significant presence of antifungal-resistant fungi, suggesting that occupational exposure to mycotoxins is a hazard. The results indicate that microbial contamination is a prominent occupational risk, especially during the milling stage of coffee production.

Objectives: The main purpose of this study was to examine the feasibility of using a wearable insole pressure system to automatically recognize overexertion-related activities among construction workers and to assess their ergonomic risk levels.
Problem: The study addresses the lack of focused research on the automated recognition of overexertion-related construction workers' activities and the assessment of ergonomic risk levels, which are crucial for minimizing work-related musculoskeletal disorders (WMSDs) among construction workers.
Data: The data utilized in the study included acceleration and foot plantar pressure distribution data, captured by a wearable insole pressure system.
Methods_Techniques: The study employed five types of supervised machine learning classifiers to assess classification accuracy using different window sizes. These classifiers were tested in a lab setting by simulating overexertion-related construction activities. The study also used cross-validation to evaluate performance metrics like classification accuracy and sensitivity.
Results: The results demonstrated that the Random Forest classifier with a 2.56-second window size achieved the highest classification accuracy of 98.3%, and a sensitivity of more than 95.8% for each category of activities. Furthermore, the assessment of corresponding ergonomic risk levels consistently aligned with the actual levels of risk. These findings support the development of a noninvasive wearable insole pressure system for continuous monitoring and automated activity recognition. This system could help researchers and safety managers identify and assess overexertion-related construction activities to minimize the risk of developing WMSDs among workers.

Objectives: The main purpose of this study was to explore the internal relationships between different mining safety hazards and the patterns of these occurrences using big data analysis.

Objectives: The main purpose of the study was to enhance health and safety (H&S) risk management in power infrastructure projects by developing deep learning models.

Methods_Techniques: A text-mining approach was employed to extract meaningful terms from the data and develop six deep learning models using the H2O framework of the R language. The models developed include DNNclassify (to classify risk or no risk), DNNreg1 (loss time), DNNreg2 (body injury), DNNreg3 (plant and fleet), DNNreg4 (equipment), and DNNreg5 (environment).
Results: The deep learning models demonstrated high performance, with the classification model achieving an overall accuracy of 0.93 and the regression models averaging an R^2 value of 0.92. These models, alongside a developed user-interface module, are expected to help practitioners better understand and manage H&S challenges, reduce project costs, and implement effective risk mitigation strategies.

Objectives: The main purpose of this study was to develop a robust and accurate prediction model using machine learning to forecast imminent accidents in power infrastructure projects, facilitating proactive risk mitigation strategies.

Data: The study used 1,349,239 data points from an incident dataset pertaining to power infrastructure projects.
Methods_Techniques: A particle swarm optimization approach was proposed for both feature selection and parameter tuning of the gradient boosting machine technique.
Results: The results indicated that the proposed method achieved nearly perfect predictions on test data, with a classification accuracy of 0.878 and a coefficient of determination of 0.93 for the outcome variables ACCIDENT and INJURYFREQ. This high predictive power demonstrates that injuries follow identifiable patterns rather than occurring randomly, and that machine learning can successfully capture these patterns when applied to large datasets.

Objectives: The primary goal of this study was to enhance the classification of accident causes in the construction sector using advanced text mining and machine learning techniques.
Problem: The construction industry is one of the most hazardous sectors worldwide, leading to numerous fatalities and significant financial losses due to occupational safety issues. Existing methods for classifying accident causes may not be adequately effective.
Data: The data utilized in this study originates from the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) website.
Methods_Techniques: This research employs text mining techniques and deep neural networks specifically. GloVe word embeddings with 300 dimensions were utilized for text classification. A new model named the context connotative network (CCNet) was proposed and compared against five baseline models which include Logistic Regression (LR), K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN), Support Vector Machines (SVM), Naive Bayes (NB), and Decision Tree (DT).
Results: The findings discovered that the newly proposed CCNet model surpassed the performance of all other standard models in classifying accident causes, as evaluated by the average weighted F1 score metric. The use of GloVe embeddings proved beneficial in capturing semantic relationships, and the extraction of noun and verb phrases contributed significantly to the performance enhancement of the model.

Objectives: The main purpose of this study is to identify sectoral patterns of accident processes using narrative text information from accident reports.

These findings can assist managers and policy makers in the fields of safety to address management issues in relation to industry, source, activity, and accident results, taking into account the specific characteristics of industrial sites.

Objectives: The main purpose of the study was to develop an automatic method for recognizing construction workers' perceived levels of risk using physiological signals and machine learning techniques.

Objectives: The main purpose of the study was to utilize a Bayesian Belief Network to predict the system evolution of a cement factory, estimate the probabilities of various hazardous events, their causes and consequences, and provide a decisional support system for risk assessment.

Results: The main findings indicate that falling objects are a significant hazard in the cement industry. The study also highlighted the importance of adhering to safety instructions, specifically the wearing of individual protection equipment, to mitigate risks.

Objectives: The main purpose of this study was to explore an existing panelised floor production line to reduce ergonomic risks and enhance productivity rates.

Objectives: The main purpose of this study is to devise a method to detect roofs in site images, an essential component for automating non-compliance checking of safety standards in roofing construction.

Further work is required in semantic representation and analysis for comprehensive risk evaluation.

Additionally, the study emphasized that the use of classification trees should complement, rather than replace, traditional analysis techniques.

Workers in the template and steel zones experienced the most substantial health damage.

Objectives: The main purpose of this study was to develop a prediction model using text mining to forecast occupational accidents in the steel industry.

Objectives: The main purpose of this study was to analyze construction accident reports to prevent the reoccurrence of similar accidents and develop more effective scientific risk control plans.
Problem: The problem addressed in this study centers around the high rate of hazards in the construction industry, leading to significant human sufferings and financial losses.
Data: The data used in the study consisted of fatality and catastrophe investigation summary reports from past construction accidents.
Methods_Techniques: The study applied text mining and natural language processing (NLP) techniques. Five baseline models (Support Vector Machine (SVM), Linear Regression (LR), K-nearest Neighbor (KNN), Decision Tree (DT), and Naive Bayes (NB)), along with an ensemble model, were used to classify the causes of the accidents. The Sequential Quadratic Programming (SQP) algorithm was utilized to optimize the weight of each classifier in the ensemble model. Additionally, an unsupervised chunking approach based on grammar rules was used to identify common objects causing the accidents.
Results: The optimized ensemble model outperformed the other models in terms of the average weighted F1 score, indicating it was more effective in classification tasks, specifically in cases of low support. The study also successfully identified common hazardous objects in the construction accidents, aiding in risk mitigation. Limitations were acknowledged and suggestions for future improvements were discussed.

Objectives: The main goal of this study is to develop risk assessment models that predict the severity of inhaled nanomaterial toxicity, enabling designers to identify harmful attributes and opt for safer alternatives while achieving their functional objectives.
Problem: The study addresses the challenge of the growing number of nanomaterials, which are too numerous to test individually for toxicity through traditional animal testing. This has created a backlog of untested materials, complicating effective risk management in industry and regulation due to mismatches between actual risks and interim measures.
Data: The study utilized data from in vivo nanomaterial rodentinhalational toxicity studies, specifically examining the toxicity of inhaled nanomaterials in animal models.
Methods_Techniques: The researchers applied machine learning techniques, including regression trees and the ensemble method of random forests. These techniques were chosen for their ability to handle data records with missing information and to uncover complex relationships in data, even in nonlinear or conditional scenarios.
Results: The predictive risk model developed in the study revealed that carbon nanotube (CNT) impurities can account for up to 30% of the variance in pulmonary toxicity, while titanium dioxide nanoparticle size and aggregation influenced the toxic response by less than ±10%. Additionally, differences in Gibbs Free Energy on lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) concentrations in metal oxide nanoparticles accounted for only 4% of the total variance in observed effects, with other chemical descriptors of metal oxides being deemed unimportant.

Objectives: The main purpose of the study was to propose an automated risk estimation approach for identifying hazardous zones and estimating risk in the shipbuilding industry using deep learning methods.
